subject: RE: [junit] JUnit 4 restructuring
msgSnippet: Elliotte, Thank you for this perspective. You are absolutely right that if we had frequent releases the optimal strategy would be to conceal everything
messageBody:
Elliotte,

Thank you for this perspective. You are absolutely right that if we had frequent releases the optimal strategy would be to conceal everything possible in the framework and open it up "on demand". I don't see how to implement frequent releases with JUnit, however, since the IDE vendors bake JUnit into their offerings and we don't have any infrastructure to push updates. Perhaps I am just fussing about this, or there is a simple solution. I am open to suggestions.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Elliotte Rusty Harold
> Sent: Wednesday, November 02, 2005 7:14 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 restructuring
>
> Kent Beck wrote:
>
> > However, as Erich is at pains to explain to me frequently,
> that is not the context in which we are writing JUnit. We
> need to balance the need for flexibility of extension with
> the need for flexibility of design evolution. Revealing all
> the details of our implementation means we can't change
> anything. And so we are left, as you said, revealing only as
> much as we are certain will be useful.
>
> I basically agree with that. Protected methods are fine, as long as
> you're reasonably confident they're right and you're willing
> to maintain
> them in the future.
>
> > This leaves me unsettled. I know that my frameworks aren't
> as useful as they could be, but I also know that I would
> regret opening them up completely. I don't see how to strike
> a better balance than we strike with JUnit, though, so I'll
> live with it.
>
> I think extreme programming/agile development offers a path
> out of this
> conundrum. Instead of looking for one big bang release that
> then stands
> untouched for a few years, look to more incremental releases (like in
> the earlier days of JUnit). Two week release cycles give you
> plenty of
> opportunities to open up the framework to extension as people
> actually
> need and request the extension. I've found by experience that
> I tend to
> be very bad at predicting what actually will be needed, even
> by myself.
> Therefore the longer I can delay the decision, the more likely it is
> that the eventual decision will be correct.
>
> Of course, at least half of this is stuff I learned first from your
> book. :-)
